Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid in glazed composition; slightly domed and plain back with straight sides; underside bearing possibly stamped, very debased hieroglyphic inscription arranged in register composition: central men-draughtboard sign (?), repeated twice and reduced to series of square pellets with lower and upper registers occupied by a vertical stroke flanked by sun-discs or small circles; pierced through diameter; smooth and thin glaze, slightly greenish turquoise but mainly appearing now whitish buff in colour.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: The scaraboid belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII C, subtype C10-15, see especially C12 for this piece) and produced in Naukratis (on the various productions of the 'Scarab Factory', see Webb forthcoming). Gorton identified the motif as a debased inscription, possibly mentioning the name men-ib-Ra - which should be corrected in Menekhib, the Horus name of Psamtek II - or wah-ib-Ra (Gorton 1996, 106). This debased inscription could also be the name of the god Amun-Ra written in a cryptic way (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions for this type of inscription (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, 65-70). For similar examples from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1643; BM 1886,0401.1644; Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis.8; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.696; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1888.207; Dundee, McManus Galleries 1975-61(2). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford, 93, 105-107, type XXVIII C. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, Pl. XXXVII, 70. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 70)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 106, Type XXVIII C12)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.047) (phase 3)
Condition: Fair, though glaze lost most of its colour
